BE11:22am

Two weeks ago, we discussed how several bearish factors have recently converged upon the oil markets to drive a sharp downward correction in oil prices. While the main fundamental instigator of this deteriorating oil market sentiment was clearly the Trump administration granting sanction waivers to several importers of Iranian crude, the extreme oil price meltdown over the past two
weeks has been more of a technical breakdown that has evolved into a full-blown “algorithm-fueled” selling stampede. Despite the recent meltdown in the “charts”, our job is to focus on industry fundamentals, and we think these fundamentals continue to look VERY bullish over the next few years. Going further, market concerns over slowing global oil demand growth are simply not
supported by recent data. Specifically, the recent global stock market correction combined with fears around the strengthening U.S. dollar, and rising trade tensions have raised investor fears that global oil demand growth is poised to deteriorate sharply next year.

BE11:23am

While we are certainly concerned about the potential impact from a rising U.S. dollar, all of the most recently available oil demand data suggests that global oil demand growth remains exceptionally robust in the face of higher oil prices this year.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Furthermore, we have long held that limited global oil supplies in 2020 [and beyond], will force global oil prices high enough to meaningfully slow global oil demand growth in the out-years.

FATDAZ RE Brent If I may I will just reference a comment from Fast FT on Friday for some perspective on todays moves https://i.gyazo.com/02473515a73075976081a9e45e69855e.png

BE11:25am

The fact is, global oil demand this year has held up much better than many expected (or feared) in the face of rising oil prices. While oil demand has historically been very sensitive to pricing, the data so far this year does NOT show a dramatic oil demand slowdown due to higher prices this year. Again, given our aboveconsensus
oil price forecast going into 2020, we naturally believe that global oil demand growth must slow. As detailed in the chart above, global demand growth has gone through several distinct periods over the past two decades despite averaging 1.4% annual growth over the past 30 years. Twenty years ago, the “old school” low oil price period of strong but ratable demand growth saw an above average growth of ~1.6 million bpd per year. That reversed after the 2008 financial crisis and ~$100/Bbl crude prices tempered demand down to ~1 million bpd from 2008 through 2013. Subsequently, falling oil prices beginning in 2014 fueled a multiyear upswing in very robust oil demand growth (~1.8 million bpd – or 1.9% average annual growth, well above the long-term trend). More recently, we expect rising oil prices to modestly slow the 2018 growth rate to around ~1.4 million bpd, which is more in-line with the 30-year growth rate. With our recently increased oil price assumptions, we now model global oil demand growth slowing to 1.3 million bpd in 2019 and falling further to only 1.0 million bpd of growth in 2020 and beyond. If oil prices stay here, our 2019 oil demand estimates will be too low.

BE11:27am

Ahead of the crucial 5-6 December OPEC meeting in Vienna, expect extreme volatility in oil prices to prevail, as markets are looking for answers from OPEC (i.e. Saudi Arabia), Russia, the US E&P operators and US President Trump (who has been adding fuel to the fire with his recent tweets). Saudi Arabia’s position has clearly been weakened by the Khashoggi assassination, and that is also adding to the market’s anxiety ahead of the crucial 5-6 December meeting. The short-term outlook for oil prices remains more uncertain than ever, although we are confident that OPEC will make the required cuts. Longer term, we believe a Brent price of USD65/bbl would strike the right balance.

A. M. (as mosschops rightly said)
BE11:28am

Under our revised oil price deck, we cut our cash flow estimates by c. 9% and our TP by 7%. We stay positive on Big Oils as dividends (yield 5%) are safe even in a sub USD55/bbl world while FCF yield at Brent USD65/bbl by 2020E is close to 10%. A full sensitivity analysis is inside the report including the FCF yield at various oil price scenarios and an SOP valuation (forex Brent). The sector has been hit hard by recent oil price sell-offs, although the long-end of the curve stays around USD63/bbl. Our most preferred names are Total, BP, Equinor, Repsol and Eni, all of which offer +25% upside.

BE11:31am

Last Tuesday saw the single largest percentage increase in crude volatility ever recorded. This is critical as lower volatility begets larger positions and increased liquidity that allows markets to function smoothly. However, once the confidence in stability is tested without a backstop, volatility rises and higher volatility leads to smaller positions, which reinforces higher volatility and less risk capital in the market. This can be seen in the sharp decline in oil open interest over the past month (see Exhibit 6). Exacerbating the situation was a negative gamma event as we discussed two weeks ago. At $50/bbl WTI, however, we are now on the other side of the largest number of puts struck at $55/bbl (see Exhibit 7) which creates the need for swap dealers who are delta hedging the producer puts to begin to buy again. This is why we feel the time is right to start recommending a long position in oil at these levels.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

In our view the current environment is simply unsustainable. Either discretionary money will come into the markets should US/Chinese policymakers create market confidence in the coming weeks or the physical markets will ultimately correct the paper markets sometime during 2019. In any case, both solutions point to higher commodity prices and an opportunity for discretionary investors to take advantage of severely dislocated markets. We believe that there are three key policy areas that have created the lack of discretionary investment in commodities: tax policy, trade war and foreign policy, particularly with respect to Iran. The tax policy not only stimulated the US and made US assets more attractive, which strengthened the dollar and acted as a headwind to commodity prices, it also incentivized substantial dollar repatriation, which supported the dollar and hurt commodity investments, particularly industrial and precious metal prices. The tax policy is mostly in the rear view mirror now and our economists believe the last of the stimulus will fade during 1H19. We believe the best way to trade the dislocation created by excessive US optimism is via gold and are recommending an outright long gold position.

wayneJ Daft question - is it more fruitful to model global oil supply and demand or model Saudi and Russian balance sheet and cashflow. I appreciate that a lot of this is shrouded in mystery but would it be more insightful on local concerns?
BE11:34am

And here they are on oil.

BE11:34am

While we didn’t think that Brent prices were justified at $86/bbl, neither do we believe that they are at $59/bbl with our 2019 Brent forecast at $70/bbl. Based on our economists’ outlook, we first expect demand growth to remain resilient (1.6 and 1.5 mb/d this year and next) with 2018 demand levels also likely understated. Second, we expect that Iran exports will continue to decline through 2019. Third, at current prices we expect fiscal strains for both OPEC and US shale producers to lead to lower production. Key to the timing of a price recovery will be whether OPEC+ commits to a cut in production at their upcoming December 6 meeting or whether low prices force them and US producers to act later next year. The uncertainty over what history suggests should be a straightforward decision comes from President Trump’s continued support for lower oil prices. Ultimately, we believe that OPEC will start reducing production in December as the fiscal strains at current prices are too elevated to ignore, with WTI prices also at levels that would weigh on US economic growth. As negative gamma effects were key to the overshoot in prices to current levels, it is also important to note that prices are now at the bottom of the range where such effects play out, leaving the next volatile move as to the upside instead of the downside. Net, while we believe it will take fundamental evidence for prices to meaningfully recover, we view the balance of risks as skewed to higher prices here. Such a recovery in prices will require that the Brent forward curve normalizes from its sudden and excessive move into contango, as greater visibility in future sources of supply keep a lid on deferred prices. After their recent collapse, we view oil futures - both in level, volatility and curvature - as having overshot the softening in fundamentals in both prompt and 2019 oil balances.

Here's RBC.

BE11:38am

DNO this morning announced a 152p per share cash offer for Faroe. This bid represents a 21% premium to Friday’s close, but we believe it probably comes too soon after Faroe's 170p peak (1st October) to win over shareholders this morning.

The E&P sector is enduring some turmoil but we would expect investors to see what OPEC does in early December before resetting their oil price expectations for 2019+. Moreover, the tone of the offer looks set to bring “relatively small scale, financially constrained” Faroe, “whose share price has remained stubbornly disappointing”, coming out fighting … we expect the stock to trade above 152p this morning.

BE11:39am

Based upon our calculations this offer equates to a bid for Faroe’s Tangible assets at $56-57/bbl, which is not far from the sector average, but shareholders would be hoping for a premium that reflects its growth potential. Moreover, DNO should rerate after establishing a sizeable position in the North Sea as result of a reduction in the perceived WACC, and we would expect Faroe’s shareholders to seek payment for that uplift.

Things are just kicking off…

red @Tony...oil inflation/deflation isnt an instant as far as cpi goes, it takes time to filter into real data. you also need to remember fed has been raising without really strong inflation growth - they want to get to a better place in time for next recession. they may stop raising but only if US growth slows - and that would be bad for oil
11:39 am
BE11:39am

And Jefferies.

BE11:39am

DNO all-cash offer of 152p/sh for FPM materially undervalues the company, in our view. Offer implies $7/boe EV/2P reserves. Our 190p price target for FPM implies $9/boe 2P reserves. Precedent Listed-E&P take-outs suggest double-digit 2P take out metrics at least. If we include FPM's 2C resources, the bid implies $3.2/boe EV/2P+2C, an even greater discount to precedent transactions.

£2/sh would be needed to match the lowest 2P+2C precedent of $5.8/boe.

DNO bids $7/boe for FPM...Our PT says $9/boe...Norway precedent says higher. DNO's (DNO NO, NC) all-cash 152p/sh offer for Faroe Petroleum (FPM LN, Buy, 190p PT) implies US$6.9/boe for FPM's 98mmboe of 2P reserves which under-values versus precedent transactions and versus the capability and delivery of FPM management team's longer-term strategy.

Reasons to be more cheerful for 2019. Our improving optimism is based on 4 key broad
trends – (1) we don’t believe upstream spending was predicated on ‘oil at USD80/b’, so see
limited impact from the oil market correction, and also note spending growth in natural gas/LNG,
not oil alone, (2) the simple passage of time means we’re now moving into a year (2019) where
international spending activity looks set to see gradual but consistent improvement, (3) the US
Lower 48 shale story is tracking a visible pipeline expansion dynamic through 2019/2020, and
(4) due to the recent financial market correction, many of the growth, activity, and expectationlinked
risks in this sector look in our view much more fairly priced.

FATDAZ @excel it does indeed but in terms of inflation expectations the Bond breakevens are the items that are immediately influenced by oil price changes or so it seems to me
BE11:46am

What’s changed from our viewpoint – our optimism from an investment viewpoint is at least
as much driven by the emerging value in this sector from lower share prices, as it is from any
structural change in the rate of recovery. But the overall fundamental investing picture looks, in
our view, more promising now that many valuations are back to average (or below average)
historical levels. This, plus improved visibility into 2019, has supported our upgrades to Buy for
SLB, WG, and SPM, arguably the most diversified players in this sector, and the removal of our
negative rating on FTI (upgrade to Hold). We now have no Reduce ratings across the
developed market or the emerging market OFS names.

We have cut near-term North American margin forecasts for the ‘Big 3’, but with a broad-based recovery likely in 2019, we see increasing opportunity. We upgrade SLB and WG to Buy from Hold; both offer diversified exposure to recovery at the right price. Offshore is still in early recovery, and consensus is still optimistic over margins, but lower valuations balance this risk/reward.

We see more opportunity in US shale-exposed industrials names in the UK with Buy-rated WEIR, ROR and IMI.
